bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 10, 1906

div1.p: Gorgas discusses career and salary issues and concerns. Gorgas supports James Carroll for the Nobel Prize.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, August 10, 1906

opener.dateline:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
----
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, C. Z.
August 10th 1906.

div1.p:
Shimer has asked to be relieved
& I am looking around for some
one with Corps to take his place.

Would you care to come down
Your salary would be 5250 with
quarters and I would consider
you in line of promotion just after
Phillips or rather Perry. As we
stand now I come with ten thousand
Carter eight, Phillip seven, Perry
seven. If a vacancy shoud
occur I would recommend Carter's
to go up, Phillips to succeed Carter &
if you were here, you to succeed
Phillips. I think that we are going
2
to have changes within the next few
months & that my power will be
considerably increased and that my
recommendation would hold in these
promotions. But you understand
that at Panama nothing but the
present is certain. You have now
been with Surgeon Generals Office
nearly four years & I thought some
change might be contemplated & for
a family man who has been in
Washington four years and for
as the increase in salary might be
attractive.

I inclose your letter recently written
to Ronald Ross. I think it would
be a well deserved honor for Carroll
and quite a feather in the cap of
our corps if the Nobel Prize could
go to Carroll. The Surgeon General
might find opportunity to advance it.
